<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:19.98PT; WIDTH:456PT; LINE-HEIGHT:11PT;FONT-WEIGHT:BOLD;">
	Factors Affecting Our Operating Results
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="TEXT-INDENT:20PT; MARGIN-TOP:6PT; WIDTH:456PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	We believe there are several important factors that have affected and that we expect to continue to affect our results of operations:
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; WIDTH:456PT; LINE-HEIGHT:11PT;FONT-STYLE:ITALIC;FONT-WEIGHT:BOLD;">
	Revenues
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT:20PT; MARGIN-TOP:6PT; WIDTH:436PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	We evaluate segment performance based on our operating income in our two segments.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="TEXT-INDENT:20PT; MARGIN-TOP:6PT; WIDTH:456PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-STYLE:ITALIC;">
	Sales to OEMs
</FONT>
	.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We supply our technology to OEMs through our arrangements with automotive system integrators, known as Tier 1 companies, which are direct suppliers to OEMs. Our products are ultimately integrated into a new vehicle by the OEM to perform ADAS functions. We have strong direct relationships with OEMs. Mobileye&#8217;s OEM products have been available in production vehicles since 2007. Sales to OEMs represented approximately 84%, 85% and 78% of our total revenues for each of the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2015, 2014 and 2013, respectively.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="TEXT-INDENT:20PT; MARGIN-TOP:6PT; WIDTH:456PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-STYLE:ITALIC;">
	Aftermarket Product Sales
</FONT>
	.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We also offer our ADAS technology as an aftermarket product directly and through distributors to end customers, including commercial and governmental fleet owners, fleet management system providers, insurance companies, new vehicle dealers and importers. Mobileye&#8217;s aftermarket products have been sold since 2007. Our aftermarket sales represented approximately 16%, 15% and 22% of our total revenues for each of the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2015, 2014 and 2013, respectively.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="TEXT-INDENT:20PT; MARGIN-TOP:6PT; WIDTH:456PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	We believe there are two important factors that affect both our OEM revenues and, to a lesser extent, our aftermarket product revenues:
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE=" FLOAT:LEFT; MARGIN-LEFT:20PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT; MARGIN-TOP:9.98PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-ALIGN:LEFT; WIDTH:20PT;WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP;">
	&#8226;
<BR>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE=" FLOAT:LEFT; MARGIN-TOP:9.98PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT; TEXT-ALIGN:LEFT; WIDTH:415.5PT;">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-STYLE:ITALIC;">
	Regulation and NCAP ratings
</FONT>
	&#8201;&#8212;&#8201;The continual emphasis on safety is driven both by regulation and the availability to consumers of independent assessments of the safety performance of different car models, which have encouraged OEMs to produce cars that are safer than those required by law. In many countries, NCAPs have created a &#8220;market for safety.&#8221; OEMs seek to demonstrate that their new and revamped car models satisfy the NCAP&#8217;s highest rating, typically five stars, or can &#8220;tick the box&#8221; on the new car sticker. National NCAPs will continue to add specific ADAS applications to their evaluation items over the next several years. We believe that this global rollout will also lead to harmonized requirements across key geographic areas. We further believe that these increasing requirements will help us increase our revenues.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="CLEAR:BOTH; PADDING:0PT; MARGIN:0PT;FONT-SIZE:0PT;LINE-HEIGHT:0PT;">
	&#8203;
</DIV>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="CLEAR:BOTH;FONT-SIZE:0PT;">
	&#8203;
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:16PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:21.71PT;MARGIN-LEFT:70PT;WIDTH:456PT;">
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:5PT; TEXT-ALIGN:CENTER; WIDTH:456PT; LINE-HEIGHT:11PT;">
	54
</DIV>
</DIV>
<HR>
</DIV>
<A NAME="eolPage57"></A>
<DIV STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-AFTER:ALWAYS; WIDTH:595.3PT;FONT-STYLE:NORMAL;FONT-WEIGHT:NORMAL;FONT-VARIANT:NORMAL;TEXT-TRANSFORM:NONE;COLOR:#000000;FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF;FONT-SIZE:10PT;">
<DIV STYLE="PADDING:0PT;MARGIN:0PT;FONT-FAMILY:CALIBRI, ARIAL, SANS-SERIF;FONT-WEIGHT:NORMAL;FONT-STYLE:NORMAL;FONT-SIZE:8PT;LINE-HEIGHT:8PT;">
<A STYLE="TEXT-DECORATION:NONE;COLOR:#003366;" HREF="#T1600459-20F_HTM_TOC">
	TABLE OF CONTENTS
</A>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:46PT;MARGIN-LEFT:70PT;WIDTH:456PT;">
<DIV STYLE=" FLOAT:LEFT; MARGIN-LEFT:20PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT; MARGIN-TOP:4PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-ALIGN:LEFT; WIDTH:20PT;WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP;">
	&#8226;
<BR>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE=" FLOAT:LEFT; MARGIN-TOP:4PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT; TEXT-ALIGN:LEFT; WIDTH:415.5PT;">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-STYLE:ITALIC;">
	Consumer awareness and acceptance of ADAS
</FONT>
	&#8201;&#8212;&#8201;Our sales are also driven by public awareness and demand for driver safety technology. In recent years, as regulatory requirements and NCAP ratings have increased, OEMs have also begun to highlight their safety features as a competitive advantage. For example, an OEM emphasized its safety features based on Mobileye technology in an advertisement during the 2016 Super Bowl.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="CLEAR:BOTH; PADDING:0PT; MARGIN:0PT;FONT-SIZE:0PT;LINE-HEIGHT:0PT;">
	&#8203;
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="TEXT-INDENT:20PT; MARGIN-TOP:6PT; WIDTH:456PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	We believe these factors will have a greater impact on our OEM segment, which, based in part on the expected additional serial production already sourced from us through 2018, is expected to grow more rapidly than our aftermarket segment.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="TEXT-INDENT:20PT; MARGIN-TOP:6PT; WIDTH:456PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	The ASP for our OEM products is primarily based on the bundle of applications that are included in the specific product. Each OEM determines the application bundle set that it wants for the particular model.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="TEXT-INDENT:20PT; MARGIN-TOP:6PT; WIDTH:456PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	Our ASP for the aftermarket is primarily based on the sales channel and volume. Generally, when we sell directly to the end customer, our ASP is higher than when we sell through distributors. Recently, as a result of increased sales in Israel, our revenue in the AM segment has also been affected by movements of the U.S. dollar against the New Israeli Shekel. In the past most of our aftermarket sales have been to commercial and fleet customers. We believe there is significant potential for growth in other sub-segments such as insurance companies and governmental incentive programs, which are focused on saving lives and reducing the number of road accidents.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="TEXT-INDENT:20PT; MARGIN-TOP:6PT; WIDTH:456PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	Although parts of the automotive industry are subject to seasonality, depending on the location of the OEM and other factors, it is not yet clear whether seasonality will affect our results of operations because our continuing growth in revenues has masked any seasonality impact.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; WIDTH:456PT; LINE-HEIGHT:11PT;FONT-STYLE:ITALIC;FONT-WEIGHT:BOLD;">
	Cost of Revenues and Gross Profit
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="TEXT-INDENT:20PT; MARGIN-TOP:6PT; WIDTH:456PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	Cost of revenues of our OEM segment includes the manufacturing cost of our EyeQ
<FONT STYLE=" POSITION:RELATIVE; BOTTOM:4.25PT;FONT-SIZE:7.5PT;">
	&reg;
</FONT>
	chips as well as royalty fees for few third parties on intellectual property that is included in the EyeQ
<FONT STYLE=" POSITION:RELATIVE; BOTTOM:4.25PT;FONT-SIZE:7.5PT;">
	&reg;
</FONT>
	SoC, product liability insurance, reserves for estimated warranty expenses and, to the extent relevant, charges to write down the carrying value of our inventory when it exceeds its estimated net realizable value and to provide for obsolete and on-hand inventory in excess of forecasted demand.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="TEXT-INDENT:20PT; MARGIN-TOP:6PT; WIDTH:456PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	Cost of revenues of our aftermarket product includes, in addition to the cost of the EyeQ
<FONT STYLE=" POSITION:RELATIVE; BOTTOM:4.25PT;FONT-SIZE:7.5PT;">
	&reg;
</FONT>
	chips (including royalties), direct material, labor costs, depreciation, manufacturing and supply chain overhead, quality control, shipping and logistic costs and reserves for estimated warranty expenses. Cost of revenues also includes charges to write down the carrying value of our inventory when it exceeds its estimated net realizable value and to provide for obsolete and on-hand inventory in excess of forecasted demand. We purchase the majority of the components directly and our products are manufactured primarily by one contract manufacturer in China.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="TEXT-INDENT:20PT; MARGIN-TOP:6PT; WIDTH:456PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	Our gross profit equals total revenues less our total cost of revenues, and our gross margin is our gross profit expressed as a percentage of total revenues.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT:20PT; MARGIN-TOP:6PT; WIDTH:436PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	Our cost of revenue is expected to increase as our sales continue to grow.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; WIDTH:456PT; LINE-HEIGHT:11PT;FONT-STYLE:ITALIC;FONT-WEIGHT:BOLD;">
	Research and Development Expenses
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="TEXT-INDENT:20PT; MARGIN-TOP:6PT; WIDTH:456PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	Research and development activities are conducted primarily at our machine vision center in Jerusalem, Israel. Our activities are divided among:
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE=" FLOAT:LEFT; MARGIN-LEFT:20PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT; MARGIN-TOP:9.98PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-ALIGN:LEFT; WIDTH:20PT;WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP;">
	&#8226;
<BR>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE=" FLOAT:LEFT; MARGIN-TOP:9.98PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT; TEXT-ALIGN:LEFT; WIDTH:415.5PT;">
	Core sensing technology, which include (i)&nbsp;algorithms, including visual processing, camera control, vehicle control, camera/radar fusion and related engineering tasks and (ii)&nbsp;application software;
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="CLEAR:BOTH; PADDING:0PT; MARGIN:0PT;FONT-SIZE:0PT;LINE-HEIGHT:0PT;">
	&#8203;
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE=" FLOAT:LEFT; MARGIN-LEFT:20PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT; MARGIN-TOP:9.98PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-ALIGN:LEFT; WIDTH:20PT;WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP;">
	&#8226;
<BR>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE=" FLOAT:LEFT; MARGIN-TOP:9.98PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT; TEXT-ALIGN:LEFT; WIDTH:415.5PT;">
	Autonomous Driving Functionality, which consists of&#8201; (i)&nbsp;enhancing the sensing capabilities to fully autonomous driving by conducting &#8220;scene understanding,&#8221; lateral control algorithms and the fusion between sensing and control; (ii)&nbsp;developing the other pillars of autonomous driving,
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="CLEAR:BOTH; PADDING:0PT; MARGIN:0PT;FONT-SIZE:0PT;LINE-HEIGHT:0PT;">
	&#8203;
</DIV>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="CLEAR:BOTH;FONT-SIZE:0PT;">
	&#8203;
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:16PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:21.71PT;MARGIN-LEFT:70PT;WIDTH:456PT;">
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:5PT; TEXT-ALIGN:CENTER; WIDTH:456PT; LINE-HEIGHT:11PT;">
	55
</DIV>
</DIV>
<HR>
</DIV>
<A NAME="eolPage58"></A>
<DIV STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-AFTER:ALWAYS; WIDTH:595.3PT;FONT-STYLE:NORMAL;FONT-WEIGHT:NORMAL;FONT-VARIANT:NORMAL;TEXT-TRANSFORM:NONE;COLOR:#000000;FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF;FONT-SIZE:10PT;">
<DIV STYLE="PADDING:0PT;MARGIN:0PT;FONT-FAMILY:CALIBRI, ARIAL, SANS-SERIF;FONT-WEIGHT:NORMAL;FONT-STYLE:NORMAL;FONT-SIZE:8PT;LINE-HEIGHT:8PT;">
<A STYLE="TEXT-DECORATION:NONE;COLOR:#003366;" HREF="#T1600459-20F_HTM_TOC">
	TABLE OF CONTENTS
</A>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:46PT;MARGIN-LEFT:70PT;WIDTH:456PT;">
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT:40PT; WIDTH:416PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	including our REM technology, which enables continuously updated high-definition data for drivable paths with precise-localization using crowd sourcing; and (iii)&nbsp;driving policy using reinforcement technology to allow autonomous cars to co-exist with human drivers and other autonomous cars;
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE=" FLOAT:LEFT; MARGIN-LEFT:20PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT; MARGIN-TOP:3.02PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-ALIGN:LEFT; WIDTH:20PT;WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP;">
	&#8226;
<BR>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE=" FLOAT:LEFT; MARGIN-TOP:3.02PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT; TEXT-ALIGN:LEFT; WIDTH:415.5PT;">
	New products and enhancements to existing products in response to OEM requirements; and
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="CLEAR:BOTH; PADDING:0PT; MARGIN:0PT;FONT-SIZE:0PT;LINE-HEIGHT:0PT;">
	&#8203;
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE=" FLOAT:LEFT; MARGIN-LEFT:20PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT; MARGIN-TOP:3.01PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-ALIGN:LEFT; WIDTH:20PT;WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP;">
	&#8226;
<BR>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE=" FLOAT:LEFT; MARGIN-TOP:3.01PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT; TEXT-ALIGN:LEFT; WIDTH:415.5PT;">
	Hardware, which includes (i)&nbsp;silicon design for the EyeQ
<FONT STYLE=" POSITION:RELATIVE; BOTTOM:4.25PT;FONT-SIZE:7.5PT;">
	&reg;
</FONT>
	chip including the EyeQ4
<FONT STYLE=" POSITION:RELATIVE; BOTTOM:4.25PT;FONT-SIZE:7.5PT;">
	&reg;
</FONT>
	; (ii)&nbsp;hardware electronics design for testing and other equipment; and (iii)&nbsp;new aftermarket hardware; for example, we are currently developing the next generation of our aftermarket products incorporating the EyeQ3
<FONT STYLE=" POSITION:RELATIVE; BOTTOM:4.25PT;FONT-SIZE:7.5PT;">
	&reg;
</FONT>
	chip.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="CLEAR:BOTH; PADDING:0PT; MARGIN:0PT;FONT-SIZE:0PT;LINE-HEIGHT:0PT;">
	&#8203;
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="TEXT-INDENT:20PT; MARGIN-TOP:6PT; WIDTH:456PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	Research and development expenses primarily consist of expenses related to personnel, including share-based compensation, material, parts and other prototype development, consulting and other professional services, amortized equipment expense and quality assurance within the development programs.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="TEXT-INDENT:20PT; MARGIN-TOP:6PT; WIDTH:456PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	Our research and development expenses are partially offset by non-refundable Non-Recurring Engineering reimbursement that we receive mostly from Tier 1&#8217;s attributable to specific development programs with the OEMs. Any such reimbursement is not contingent upon success of the program. We retain all the rights to our work on these programs.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="TEXT-INDENT:20PT; MARGIN-TOP:6PT; WIDTH:456PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	We intend to continue our significant investment in research and development activities as we believe that being the technology leader and the most innovative company in ADAS and autonomous driving is our key strength. Accordingly, we expect the absolute amount of our research and development expenses to increase but it is likely to decrease as a percentage of revenue as our business grows.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; WIDTH:456PT; LINE-HEIGHT:11PT;FONT-STYLE:ITALIC;FONT-WEIGHT:BOLD;">
	Sales and Marketing
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="TEXT-INDENT:20PT; MARGIN-TOP:6PT; WIDTH:456PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	Selling and marketing expenses consist of personnel and personnel-related expenses, including share-based compensation, of our sales force as well as advertising and marketing expenses. We expect to increase our sales and marketing activities, mainly in order to increase our aftermarket sales. We expect to increase our sales and marketing expenses as we continue our efforts to increase market awareness of the benefits of ADAS and to increase our aftermarket segment revenues, but in the long-term, sales and marketing expenses should decrease as a percentage of revenue as our business grows over time.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; WIDTH:456PT; LINE-HEIGHT:11PT;FONT-STYLE:ITALIC;FONT-WEIGHT:BOLD;">
	General and Administrative Expenses
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="TEXT-INDENT:20PT; MARGIN-TOP:6PT; WIDTH:456PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	General and administrative expenses consist of personnel and personnel-related expenses, including share-based compensation, of our executive and members of the board of directors, finance and administration departments as well as fees related to legal and litigation, patent prosecution, accounting, finance and professional services as well as insurance and, fees related to being a public company. We expect the amount of our general and administrative expenses to increase but to decrease over time as a percentage of revenue as our business grows. The primary reasons for the growth in general and administrative expenses will be the costs related to patents prosecution, including the need to hire more personnel to support compliance with the applicable provisions of SOX and other SEC rules and NYSE regulations as well as increased premiums for director and officers insurance and the increased use of share-based compensation for general and administrative personnel.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; WIDTH:456PT; LINE-HEIGHT:11PT;FONT-STYLE:ITALIC;FONT-WEIGHT:BOLD;">
	Interest Income
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="TEXT-INDENT:20PT; MARGIN-TOP:6PT; WIDTH:456PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	Interest income consists of interest earned on marketable securities as well as short-term deposits and money market funds. We have historically invested our available cash balances primarily in short-term deposits and debentures. The primary objective of our investments in debt instruments is to preserve principal while maximizing yields.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; WIDTH:456PT; LINE-HEIGHT:11PT;FONT-STYLE:ITALIC;FONT-WEIGHT:BOLD;">
	Financial Income (Expenses), net
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="TEXT-INDENT:20PT; MARGIN-TOP:6PT; WIDTH:456PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	Financial income (expense), net, includes mainly realized gains and losses on sales of financial investments and any decline in the value which is considered not temporary, as well as gains and losses from fluctuations related to currency translation of our monetary assets and liabilities denominated in New
</DIV>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:16PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:21.71PT;MARGIN-LEFT:70PT;WIDTH:456PT;">
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:5PT; TEXT-ALIGN:CENTER; WIDTH:456PT; LINE-HEIGHT:11PT;">
	56
</DIV>
</DIV>
<HR>
</DIV>
<A NAME="eolPage59"></A>
<DIV STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-AFTER:ALWAYS; WIDTH:595.3PT;FONT-STYLE:NORMAL;FONT-WEIGHT:NORMAL;FONT-VARIANT:NORMAL;TEXT-TRANSFORM:NONE;COLOR:#000000;FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF;FONT-SIZE:10PT;">
<DIV STYLE="PADDING:0PT;MARGIN:0PT;FONT-FAMILY:CALIBRI, ARIAL, SANS-SERIF;FONT-WEIGHT:NORMAL;FONT-STYLE:NORMAL;FONT-SIZE:8PT;LINE-HEIGHT:8PT;">
<A STYLE="TEXT-DECORATION:NONE;COLOR:#003366;" HREF="#T1600459-20F_HTM_TOC">
	TABLE OF CONTENTS
</A>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:46PT;MARGIN-LEFT:70PT;WIDTH:456PT;">
<DIV STYLE="WIDTH:456PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	Israeli Shekels (&#8220;NIS&#8221;) and, to a much lesser extent, the Euro, the Japanese Yen and other currencies. We manage our main currency exposures which is against the NIS by keeping approximately the same NIS assets as our NIS liabilities to serve as a natural balance sheet hedge. Our exposure is reflected in the individual Income statement item.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; WIDTH:456PT; LINE-HEIGHT:11PT;FONT-STYLE:ITALIC;FONT-WEIGHT:BOLD;">
	Taxes on Income
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="TEXT-INDENT:20PT; MARGIN-TOP:6PT; WIDTH:456PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	Until July&nbsp;2014, Mobileye N.V. and our Cypriot subsidiary were taxed under the laws of their respective countries of incorporation. Following our reorganization (see &#8220;&#8212;&#8201;Reorganization&#8221; below), we have our headquarters in Israel, and Mobileye N.V. and our Cypriot subsidiary are residents of Israel for tax purposes. The enacted statutory tax rates applicable to us and our significant subsidiaries are as follows:
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE=" FLOAT:LEFT; MARGIN-LEFT:20PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT; MARGIN-TOP:8.59PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-ALIGN:LEFT; WIDTH:20PT;WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP;">
	&#8226;
<BR>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE=" FLOAT:LEFT; MARGIN-TOP:8.59PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT; TEXT-ALIGN:LEFT; WIDTH:415.5PT;">
	MVT, our Israeli subsidiary, is taxed under Israeli law. Income not eligible for benefits under the Investment Law (described below) is taxed at the corporate tax rate. The corporate tax rate in Israel is 25% in 2016. Corporate tax rates were 26.5% in both 2015 and 2014 and 25% in both 2013 and 2012. However, the effective tax rate payable by a company that derives income from a Benefited Enterprise or a Preferred Enterprise under the Investment Law may be considerably less. Capital gains derived by an Israeli company are subject to tax at the prevailing corporate rate.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="CLEAR:BOTH; PADDING:0PT; MARGIN:0PT;FONT-SIZE:0PT;LINE-HEIGHT:0PT;">
	&#8203;
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE=" FLOAT:LEFT; MARGIN-LEFT:20PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT; MARGIN-TOP:8.58PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-ALIGN:LEFT; WIDTH:20PT;WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP;">
	&#8226;
<BR>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE=" FLOAT:LEFT; MARGIN-TOP:8.58PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT; TEXT-ALIGN:LEFT; WIDTH:415.5PT;">
	Upon the election made by MVT in May&nbsp;2014, MVT became eligible for certain tax benefits under the 2011 Amendment (as defined below) of the Israeli Investment Law&#8201;&#8212;&#8201;&#8220;Preferred Enterprise Benefits&#8221; as of the beginning of 2014. According to the 2011 Amendment and subject to the Preferred Enterprise Ruling (as described below), our &#8220;Preferred Income&#8221; will be subject to a reduced tax rate. See &#8220;&#8212;&#8201;Tax Regime Under the 2011 Amendment (&#8220;Preferred Enterprise&#8221;)&#8221; below.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="CLEAR:BOTH; PADDING:0PT; MARGIN:0PT;FONT-SIZE:0PT;LINE-HEIGHT:0PT;">
	&#8203;
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE=" FLOAT:LEFT; MARGIN-LEFT:20PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT; MARGIN-TOP:8.78PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-ALIGN:LEFT; WIDTH:20PT;WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP;">
	&#8226;
<BR>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE=" FLOAT:LEFT; MARGIN-TOP:8.78PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT; TEXT-ALIGN:LEFT; WIDTH:415.5PT;">
	Until our internal reorganization was completed in the third quarter of 2014, most of our benefit (tax) on income was incurred from Cyprus, which was the location of our intellectual property. See &#8220;&#8212;&#8201;Reorganization&#8221; below. Our Cypriot subsidiary was taxed at the Cypriot corporate tax rate, which was 10% prior to 2013 and became 12.5% from 2013 and thereafter. Our Cypriot subsidiary could offset profits arising in future years with taxable losses (carryforward losses) for the five years prior to the fiscal year in which the losses were incurred. Interest income is taxed at the Defence tax rate, which was 30% in 2013 and thereafter (effective from May&nbsp;1, 2013) and 15% in 2012. As of the transfer of the management and control of our Cypriot subsidiary to Israel, our Cypriot subsidiary is treated as an Israeli resident for tax purposes and is taxed under the Israeli regular corporate tax rate; however, we believe that the Cypriot subsidiary will not have meaningful taxable income. See also &#8220;&#8212; Reorganization&#8221; below.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="CLEAR:BOTH; PADDING:0PT; MARGIN:0PT;FONT-SIZE:0PT;LINE-HEIGHT:0PT;">
	&#8203;
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; WIDTH:456PT; LINE-HEIGHT:11PT;FONT-STYLE:ITALIC;">
	Israeli Tax Benefits Under the Law for the Encouragement of Capital Investments, 1959
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="TEXT-INDENT:20PT; MARGIN-TOP:6PT; WIDTH:456PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	MVT has elected the &#8220;Benefited Enterprise&#8221; status under the Israeli Law for the Encouragement of Capital Investments, 1959 (the &#8220;Investment Law&#8221;). The Investment Law was significantly amended effective April&nbsp;1, 2005 (the &#8220;2005 Amendment&#8221;), and further amended as of January&nbsp;1, 2011 (the &#8220;2011 Amendment&#8221;). Pursuant to the 2005 Amendment, tax benefits granted in accordance with the provisions of the Investment Law prior to its revision by the 2005 Amendment remain in force but any benefits granted subsequently are subject to the provisions of the 2005 Amendment. Similarly, the 2011 Amendment introduced new benefits to replace those granted in accordance with the provisions of the Investment Law in effect prior to the 2011 Amendment. However, companies entitled to benefits under the Investment Law as in effect prior to January&nbsp;1, 2011 were entitled to choose to continue to enjoy such benefits, provided that certain conditions are met, or to elect irrevocably to forego such benefits and have the benefits of the 2011 Amendment apply.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; WIDTH:456PT; LINE-HEIGHT:11PT;FONT-STYLE:ITALIC;">
	Tax Regime Under the 2005 Amendment (&#8220;Benefited Enterprise&#8221;)
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="TEXT-INDENT:20PT; MARGIN-TOP:6PT; WIDTH:456PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	The extent of the tax benefits available under the 2005 Amendment to qualifying income of a Benefited Enterprise depends on, among other things, the geographic location in Israel of the Benefited Enterprise. The location will also determine the period for which tax benefits are available. Such tax benefits include an exemption from corporate tax on undistributed income for a period of between two to ten years,
</DIV>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:16PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:21.71PT;MARGIN-LEFT:70PT;WIDTH:456PT;">
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:5PT; TEXT-ALIGN:CENTER; WIDTH:456PT; LINE-HEIGHT:11PT;">
	57
</DIV>
</DIV>
<HR>
</DIV>
<A NAME="eolPage60"></A>
<DIV STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-AFTER:ALWAYS; WIDTH:595.3PT;FONT-STYLE:NORMAL;FONT-WEIGHT:NORMAL;FONT-VARIANT:NORMAL;TEXT-TRANSFORM:NONE;COLOR:#000000;FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF;FONT-SIZE:10PT;">
<DIV STYLE="PADDING:0PT;MARGIN:0PT;FONT-FAMILY:CALIBRI, ARIAL, SANS-SERIF;FONT-WEIGHT:NORMAL;FONT-STYLE:NORMAL;FONT-SIZE:8PT;LINE-HEIGHT:8PT;">
<A STYLE="TEXT-DECORATION:NONE;COLOR:#003366;" HREF="#T1600459-20F_HTM_TOC">
	TABLE OF CONTENTS
</A>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:46PT;MARGIN-LEFT:70PT;WIDTH:456PT;">
<DIV STYLE="WIDTH:456PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	depending on the geographic location of the Benefited Enterprise in Israel, and a reduced corporate tax rate of between 10% to 25% for the remainder of the &#8220;Benefits Period,&#8221; depending on the level of&#8201;&#8201; &#8220;Foreign Investment,&#8221; as defined under the Investment Law, in the company in each year. A company qualifying for tax benefits under the 2005 Amendment that pays a dividend or engages in certain actions that are treated as deemed dividends by the ITA out of income derived by its Benefited Enterprise during the tax exemption period will be subject to corporate tax in respect of the amount of the dividend (grossed-up to reflect the pre-tax income that it would have had to earn in order to distribute the dividend) at the otherwise applicable rate of 25%, or lower rates of between 10% to 25% in the case of a qualified Foreign Investors Company (&#8220;FIC&#8221;), according to the rate(s) of Foreign Investment in the company for the applicable tax year(s). Dividends paid out of income attributed to a Benefited Enterprise are generally subject to withholding tax at source at the rate of 15%, or such lower rate as may be stipulated in an applicable tax treaty provided that a certificate from the ITA allowing for the reduced withholding tax rate is obtained in advance. The benefits available to a Benefited Enterprise are subject to the fulfillment of conditions stipulated in the Investment Law, its regulations and any ruling received from the ITA. In the event of failure to comply with these conditions in a given tax year during the &#8220;Benefits Period&#8221;, the entitlement to the benefits for such tax year would be cancelled; however, the Company&#8217;s eligibility for benefits in prior and future years should not be affected.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; WIDTH:456PT; LINE-HEIGHT:11PT;FONT-STYLE:ITALIC;">
	Tax Regime Under the 2011 Amendment (&#8220;Preferred Enterprise&#8221;)
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="TEXT-INDENT:20PT; MARGIN-TOP:6PT; WIDTH:456PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	The 2011 Amendment canceled the availability of the benefits granted to companies under the Investment Law prior to 2011 and, instead, introduced new benefits for income generated by a &#8220;Preferred Company&#8221; through its &#8220;Preferred Enterprise&#8221; (as such terms are defined in the Investment Law) as of January&nbsp;1, 2011. The definition of a Preferred Company includes,
<FONT STYLE="FONT-STYLE:ITALIC;">
	inter alia
</FONT>
	, a company incorporated in Israel that is (i)&nbsp;not wholly owned by a governmental entity; (ii)&nbsp;owns a Preferred Enterprise, as defined under law; (iii)&nbsp;is controlled and managed from Israel; and (iv) fulfills certain conditions described in the Investment Law. From 2014 and thereafter a Preferred Company is entitled to a reduced corporate tax rate of 16% with respect to its income derived by its Preferred Enterprise, unless the Preferred Enterprise is located in development zone A, in which case the rate will be 9%. MVT&#8217;s activities are located in development Zone A.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="TEXT-INDENT:20PT; MARGIN-TOP:6PT; WIDTH:456PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	Dividends paid out of income attributed to a Preferred Enterprise are generally subject to withholding tax at the source at the rate of 20% with respect to dividends to be distributed after January&nbsp;1, 2014, subject to certain conditions, or such lower rate as may be provided in an applicable tax treaty provided that a certificate from the ITA allowing for the reduced withholding tax rate is obtained in advance. However, if such dividends are paid to an Israeli company, no tax is required to be withheld (although, if the funds are subsequently distributed to individuals or to a non-Israeli company, the withholding tax would apply to such subsequent distribution).
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="TEXT-INDENT:20PT; MARGIN-TOP:6PT; WIDTH:456PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	We have had Benefited Enterprise programs under the Investment Law since 2005, which, we believe, have entitled us to certain tax benefits. Additionally, in connection with the original grant of&#8201; &#8220;Benefited Enterprise&#8221; status, in 2006, MVT was recognized by the Israeli Chief Scientist Office as a &#8220;Research and Development Company.&#8221;
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="TEXT-INDENT:20PT; MARGIN-TOP:6PT; WIDTH:456PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	According to the election that we made in May&nbsp;2014 in connection with the July&nbsp;2014 ruling from the ITA (the &#8220;Preferred Enterprise Ruling&#8221;) following the reorganization described below, MVT is a &#8220;Preferred Company&#8221; under the Investment Law and is able to benefit from a reduced tax rate of approximately 9% as of the beginning of 2014, subject to the fulfillment of the terms and conditions of the law and the Preferred Enterprise Ruling. The following are the main terms and conditions of the Preferred Enterprise Ruling:
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE=" FLOAT:LEFT; MARGIN-LEFT:20PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT; MARGIN-TOP:3.02PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-ALIGN:LEFT; WIDTH:20PT;WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP;">
	&#8226;
<BR>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE=" FLOAT:LEFT; MARGIN-TOP:3.02PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT; TEXT-ALIGN:LEFT; WIDTH:415.5PT;">
	MVT is required to add 50 new manufacturing and research and development employees in each of the tax years of 2014, 2015 and 2016 and it is further required to continue employing such additional employees for the tax years until 2018. Failure to meet this term will affect the effective tax rate in a ratio related to the number of non-recruited and non-retained employees.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="CLEAR:BOTH; PADDING:0PT; MARGIN:0PT;FONT-SIZE:0PT;LINE-HEIGHT:0PT;">
	&#8203;
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE=" FLOAT:LEFT; MARGIN-LEFT:20PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT; MARGIN-TOP:3.01PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-ALIGN:LEFT; WIDTH:20PT;WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP;">
	&#8226;
<BR>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE=" FLOAT:LEFT; MARGIN-TOP:3.01PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT; TEXT-ALIGN:LEFT; WIDTH:415.5PT;">
	MVT is required to acquire 90% of its expenses from Israeli subcontractors within preferred regions compared to its total cost of goods sold and research and development to maintain the highest benefits. If the ratio is less than 90%, the tax rate will be affected in a ratio related to the portion of expenses paid to such subcontractors, all as described in the ruling.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="CLEAR:BOTH; PADDING:0PT; MARGIN:0PT;FONT-SIZE:0PT;LINE-HEIGHT:0PT;">
	&#8203;
</DIV>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="CLEAR:BOTH;FONT-SIZE:0PT;">
	&#8203;
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:16PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:21.71PT;MARGIN-LEFT:70PT;WIDTH:456PT;">
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:5PT; TEXT-ALIGN:CENTER; WIDTH:456PT; LINE-HEIGHT:11PT;">
	58
</DIV>
</DIV>

</DIV>
<A NAME="eolPage61"></A>
<DIV STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-AFTER:ALWAYS; WIDTH:595.3PT;FONT-STYLE:NORMAL;FONT-WEIGHT:NORMAL;FONT-VARIANT:NORMAL;TEXT-TRANSFORM:NONE;COLOR:#000000;FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF;FONT-SIZE:10PT;">
<DIV STYLE="PADDING:0PT;MARGIN:0PT;FONT-FAMILY:CALIBRI, ARIAL, SANS-SERIF;FONT-WEIGHT:NORMAL;FONT-STYLE:NORMAL;FONT-SIZE:8PT;LINE-HEIGHT:8PT;">
<A STYLE="TEXT-DECORATION:NONE;COLOR:#003366;" HREF="#T1600459-20F_HTM_TOC">
	TABLE OF CONTENTS
</A>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:46PT;MARGIN-LEFT:70PT;WIDTH:456PT;">
<DIV STYLE=" FLOAT:LEFT; MARGIN-LEFT:20PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT; MARGIN-TOP:4PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-ALIGN:LEFT; WIDTH:20PT;WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP;">
	&#8226;
<BR>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE=" FLOAT:LEFT; MARGIN-TOP:4PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT; TEXT-ALIGN:LEFT; WIDTH:415.5PT;">
	An MVT dividend shall be deemed first to be paid out of the undistributed income that was exempt from Israeli corporate tax generated by the Benefited Enterprise, which shall be subject to additional tax at the MVT level and to the dividend distribution provisions of income derived by a Benefited Enterprise.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="CLEAR:BOTH; PADDING:0PT; MARGIN:0PT;FONT-SIZE:0PT;LINE-HEIGHT:0PT;">
	&#8203;
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE=" FLOAT:LEFT; MARGIN-LEFT:20PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT; MARGIN-TOP:3.61PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-ALIGN:LEFT; WIDTH:20PT;WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP;">
	&#8226;
<BR>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE=" FLOAT:LEFT; MARGIN-TOP:3.61PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT; TEXT-ALIGN:LEFT; WIDTH:415.5PT;">
	ITA approval is required for MVT to transfer its intellectual property to a third party.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="CLEAR:BOTH; PADDING:0PT; MARGIN:0PT;FONT-SIZE:0PT;LINE-HEIGHT:0PT;">
	&#8203;
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE=" FLOAT:LEFT; MARGIN-LEFT:20PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT; MARGIN-TOP:3.42PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-ALIGN:LEFT; WIDTH:20PT;WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP;">
	&#8226;
<BR>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE=" FLOAT:LEFT; MARGIN-TOP:3.42PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT; TEXT-ALIGN:LEFT; WIDTH:415.5PT;">
	The Preferred Enterprise Ruling will become void in the event that MVT changes its field of activities or business model, or significantly reduces the volume of its development activity, all unless otherwise determined by the ITA.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="CLEAR:BOTH; PADDING:0PT; MARGIN:0PT;FONT-SIZE:0PT;LINE-HEIGHT:0PT;">
	&#8203;
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="TEXT-INDENT:20PT; MARGIN-TOP:6PT; WIDTH:456PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	From time to time, the Israeli Government has discussed reducing the benefits available to companies under the Investment Law. The termination or substantial reduction of any of the benefits available under the Investment Law could materially increase our tax liabilities.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; WIDTH:456PT; LINE-HEIGHT:11PT;FONT-STYLE:ITALIC;FONT-WEIGHT:BOLD;">
	Reorganization
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="TEXT-INDENT:20PT; MARGIN-TOP:6PT; WIDTH:456PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	Prior to our IPO in August&nbsp;2014, we reorganized our internal corporate structure and all of our intellectual property, formerly owned by our Cypriot subsidiary, was transferred to MVT. In connection with this reorganization, we received a tax ruling from the ITA in July&nbsp;2014 (&#8220;Reorganization Ruling&#8221;) providing that, among other matters, the reorganization would not trigger any tax in Israel and would not violate any of the Israeli tax covenants to which MVT and its shareholder are bound pursuant to a previous tax ruling. Furthermore, according to the Reorganization Ruling, the transfer of the intellectual property to MVT does not trigger tax effects in Israel in accordance with section 104B(f) of the Israeli Income Tax Ordinance (New version), 5721 &#8211; 1961 (the &#8220;Ordinance&#8221;) subject to compliance with the terms of such section and the regulations promulgated thereunder (including certain limitations on the transferability of the shares of MVT and the Cypriot subsidiary). Under the Reorganization Ruling, transfer of the intellectual property to any third party will be subject to ITA approval. We also received opinions from Cyprus counsel and Dutch counsel that the reorganization should not result in tax liabilities under the laws of Cyprus or The Netherlands although there can be no assurance that the relevant tax authorities might determine that such taxes are not owed. In addition, prior to our IPO, we took the necessary steps, including shareholder approval, to transfer all tangible assets and all liabilities of our Cypriot subsidiary to MVT, as well as to transfer the effective management of Mobileye N.V. and the management and control of our Cypriot subsidiary to Israel in order for these entities to become Israeli tax residents. The Reorganization Ruling contains additional conditions, including relating to cancellation of losses and cost basis, limitations on use of losses, credits, deductions and exemptions. See &#8220;&#8212; Taxes on Income &#8212; Tax Regime Under the 2011 Amendment (&#8220;Preferred Enterprise&#8221;).&#8221;
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; WIDTH:456PT; LINE-HEIGHT:11PT;FONT-WEIGHT:BOLD;">
	Segment Information
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="TEXT-INDENT:20PT; MARGIN-TOP:6PT; WIDTH:456PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	We manage the Company and its subsidiaries on the basis of two reportable segments. The OEM segment supplies the proprietary software algorithms and EyeQ
<FONT STYLE=" POSITION:RELATIVE; BOTTOM:4.25PT;FONT-SIZE:7.5PT;">
	&reg;
</FONT>
	chip that are the core technology of the complete ADAS to the Tier 1 companies that are the system integrators for the automotive industry. Except for limited direct sales of testing equipment to OEMs, our direct customer is the Tier 1 company with which we have a contractual relationship and which is responsible for paying us for our products. Because of the complex nature of our product and the need to customize and validate the product and to integrate it into the OEM&#8217;s overall ADAS system, we also have strong direct relationships with the OEMs. In the AM segment, the Company sells a complete system, which includes our proprietary software algorithms and EyeQ
<FONT STYLE=" POSITION:RELATIVE; BOTTOM:4.25PT;FONT-SIZE:7.5PT;">
	&reg;
</FONT>
	chip as well as the camera and other necessary components. The complete system offers a variety of ADAS functions to end customers including commercial fleet owners, new vehicle dealers and importers. We generate sales in the AM segment either directly or through distributors. For a discussion of our major customers, see Note 12(b) to our audited consolidated financial statements included elsewhere in this Annual Report on Form 20-F.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="TEXT-INDENT:20PT; MARGIN-TOP:6PT; WIDTH:456PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	Our revenues in the OEM segment increased by 66% in the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015 from the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014, and increased by 92% in the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014 from the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2013. Our revenues in the AM segment increased by 77% in the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015 from the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014 and increased by 21.6% in the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014 from the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2013.
</DIV>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:16PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:21.71PT;MARGIN-LEFT:70PT;WIDTH:456PT;">
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:5PT; TEXT-ALIGN:CENTER; WIDTH:456PT; LINE-HEIGHT:11PT;">
	59
</DIV>
</DIV>
<HR>
</DIV>
<A NAME="eolPage62"></A>
<DIV STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-AFTER:ALWAYS; WIDTH:595.3PT;FONT-STYLE:NORMAL;FONT-WEIGHT:NORMAL;FONT-VARIANT:NORMAL;TEXT-TRANSFORM:NONE;COLOR:#000000;FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF;FONT-SIZE:10PT;">
<DIV STYLE="PADDING:0PT;MARGIN:0PT;FONT-FAMILY:CALIBRI, ARIAL, SANS-SERIF;FONT-WEIGHT:NORMAL;FONT-STYLE:NORMAL;FONT-SIZE:8PT;LINE-HEIGHT:8PT;">
<A STYLE="TEXT-DECORATION:NONE;COLOR:#003366;" HREF="#T1600459-20F_HTM_TOC">
	TABLE OF CONTENTS
</A>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:46PT;MARGIN-LEFT:70PT;WIDTH:456PT;">
<DIV STYLE="TEXT-INDENT:20PT; MARGIN-TOP:6PT; WIDTH:456PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	The most material operating expenses in the OEM segment are research and development expenses, while the most material operating expenses in the AM segment are sales and marketing expenses.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT:20PT; MARGIN-TOP:6PT; WIDTH:436PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	Set forth below is selected information for each of our business segments:

<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:17PT; TEXT-ALIGN:CENTER; WIDTH:456PT; LINE-HEIGHT:11PT;FONT-WEIGHT:BOLD;">
	Segment performance as a Percentage of Total Revenues
</DIV>
<TABLE STYLE="WIDTH:416PT;HEIGHT:46.5PT;MARGIN-LEFT:20PT;MARGIN-TOP:7PT;BORDER-COLLAPSE: COLLAPSE;">
<TR STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT:8PT;WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP;TEXT-ALIGN:LEFT;VERTICAL-ALIGN:BOTTOM;FONT-STYLE:NORMAL;FONT-WEIGHT:BOLD;FONT-VARIANT:NORMAL;TEXT-TRANSFORM:NONE;COLOR:#000000;FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF;FONT-SIZE:8PT;">
<TD STYLE="BORDER-BOTTOM:1PX SOLID #FFFFFF;PADDING:0PT 0PT 0.5PT 0PT; WIDTH:266PT;">
	&#8203;
</TD>
<TD STYLE="PADDING:0PT;BORDER-BOTTOM:1PX SOLID #FFFFFF; WIDTH:6PT;">
	&#8203;

<DIV STYLE="TEXT-INDENT:20PT; MARGIN-TOP:11PT; WIDTH:456PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	For more information regarding our segments, including a reconciliation of segment performance to consolidated operating profit, see Note 11 to our audited consolidated financial statements included elsewhere in this Annual Report on Form 20-F.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="TEXT-INDENT:20PT; MARGIN-TOP:6PT; WIDTH:456PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;FONT-STYLE:ITALIC;">
	Our financial results for the periods presented below are not necessarily indicative of the financial results that we may achieve in future periods.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; WIDTH:456PT; LINE-HEIGHT:11PT;FONT-WEIGHT:BOLD;">
	Comparison of Results of Operations for 2015, 2014 and 2013
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; WIDTH:456PT; LINE-HEIGHT:11PT;FONT-STYLE:ITALIC;">
	Revenues
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="TEXT-INDENT:20PT; MARGIN-TOP:6PT; WIDTH:456PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	For the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015, our total revenue increased by $97.2 million to $240.9 million, or 68%, from $143.7 million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014. The principal factors affecting our revenue growth were:
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE=" FLOAT:LEFT; MARGIN-LEFT:20PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT; MARGIN-TOP:6.8PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-ALIGN:LEFT; WIDTH:20PT;WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP;">
	&#8226;
<BR>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE=" FLOAT:LEFT; MARGIN-TOP:6.8PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT; TEXT-ALIGN:LEFT; WIDTH:415.5PT;">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-WEIGHT:BOLD;">
	OEM
</FONT>
	&#8201;&#8212;&#8201;Revenues from OEM sales grew by approximately $80.5 million, or 66%, from 2014 to 2015: (i)&nbsp;approximately 56% of the 2015 OEM growth came from the launch of nine programs, a few of them with significant volume like Audi, GM and HKMC through Tier 1 companies
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="CLEAR:BOTH; PADDING:0PT; MARGIN:0PT;FONT-SIZE:0PT;LINE-HEIGHT:0PT;">
	&#8203;
</DIV>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="CLEAR:BOTH;FONT-SIZE:0PT;">
	&#8203;
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:16PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:21.71PT;MARGIN-LEFT:70PT;WIDTH:456PT;">
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:5PT; TEXT-ALIGN:CENTER; WIDTH:456PT; LINE-HEIGHT:11PT;">
	60
</DIV>
</DIV>
<HR>
</DIV>
<A NAME="eolPage63"></A>
<DIV STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-AFTER:ALWAYS; WIDTH:595.3PT;FONT-STYLE:NORMAL;FONT-WEIGHT:NORMAL;FONT-VARIANT:NORMAL;TEXT-TRANSFORM:NONE;COLOR:#000000;FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF;FONT-SIZE:10PT;">
<DIV STYLE="PADDING:0PT;MARGIN:0PT;FONT-FAMILY:CALIBRI, ARIAL, SANS-SERIF;FONT-WEIGHT:NORMAL;FONT-STYLE:NORMAL;FONT-SIZE:8PT;LINE-HEIGHT:8PT;">
<A STYLE="TEXT-DECORATION:NONE;COLOR:#003366;" HREF="#T1600459-20F_HTM_TOC">
	TABLE OF CONTENTS
</A>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:46PT;MARGIN-LEFT:70PT;WIDTH:456PT;">
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT:40PT; WIDTH:416PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	(ii)&nbsp;approximately 26% of the 2015 OEM growth came from the full year effect of program launches in 2014 and (iii)&nbsp;approximately 18% of the 2015 OEM growth came from increases in deliveries under programs which launched prior to 2014 which include roll-out to more models and we also believe an increase in adoption of this technology under old programs which is the result of increased market awareness.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE=" FLOAT:LEFT; MARGIN-LEFT:20PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT; MARGIN-TOP:7.39PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-ALIGN:LEFT; WIDTH:20PT;WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP;">
	&#8226;
<BR>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE=" FLOAT:LEFT; MARGIN-TOP:7.39PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT; TEXT-ALIGN:LEFT; WIDTH:415.5PT;">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-WEIGHT:BOLD;">
	AM
</FONT>
	&#8201;&#8212;&#8201;Revenues from aftermarket sales increased by $16.7 million, or 76.7%, from 2014 to 2015. The increase in 2015 was mainly related to the first full year of regulatory incentives, mainly in Israel and increased consumer market awareness. Our AM revenues were also affected by our sales channel mix. Typically, our ASP for sales through distributors is less than the ASP for direct sales. Our AM ASP decreased by 8% from 2014 to 2015, mainly due to channel mix and foreign exchange differences on revenues in New Israeli Shekels.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="CLEAR:BOTH; PADDING:0PT; MARGIN:0PT;FONT-SIZE:0PT;LINE-HEIGHT:0PT;">
	&#8203;
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="TEXT-INDENT:20PT; MARGIN-TOP:6PT; WIDTH:456PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	For the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014, our total revenue increased by $62.4 million to $143.7 million, or 76.8%, from $81.2 million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2013. The principal factors affecting our revenue growth were:
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE=" FLOAT:LEFT; MARGIN-LEFT:20PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT; MARGIN-TOP:7.39PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-ALIGN:LEFT; WIDTH:20PT;WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP;">
	&#8226;
<BR>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE=" FLOAT:LEFT; MARGIN-TOP:7.39PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT; TEXT-ALIGN:LEFT; WIDTH:415.5PT;">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-WEIGHT:BOLD;">
	OEM
</FONT>
	&#8201;&#8212;&#8201;Revenues from OEM sales grew by approximately $58.5 million, or 92.4%, from 2013 to 2014. The increase in 2014 reflected the increase in sales attributable to (i)&nbsp;the beginning of serial production, or &#8220;launch,&#8221; for nine new program launches, mainly with Ford, General Motors, HKMC and Nissan through Tier 1 companies; (ii)&nbsp;the full year effect of six launches in 2013; and (iii)&nbsp;increases in current programs assumed to result from increased market awareness and additional models launched with our technology.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="CLEAR:BOTH; PADDING:0PT; MARGIN:0PT;FONT-SIZE:0PT;LINE-HEIGHT:0PT;">
	&#8203;
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE=" FLOAT:LEFT; MARGIN-LEFT:20PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT; MARGIN-TOP:7.4PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-ALIGN:LEFT; WIDTH:20PT;WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP;">
	&#8226;
<BR>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE=" FLOAT:LEFT; MARGIN-TOP:7.4PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT; TEXT-ALIGN:LEFT; WIDTH:415.5PT;">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-WEIGHT:BOLD;">
	AM
</FONT>
	&#8201;&#8212;&#8201;Revenues from aftermarket sales increased by $3.9 million, or 21.6%, from 2013 to 2014. The increase in 2014 was mainly related to the launch of regulatory incentives, mainly in Israel. Our AM revenues were also affected by our sales channel mix. Typically, our ASP for sales through distributors is less than the ASP for direct sales. Our overall ASP decreased by 2% from 2013 to 2014, mainly due to channel mix and foreign exchange differences on revenues in New Israeli Shekels.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="CLEAR:BOTH; PADDING:0PT; MARGIN:0PT;FONT-SIZE:0PT;LINE-HEIGHT:0PT;">
	&#8203;
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; WIDTH:456PT; LINE-HEIGHT:11PT;FONT-STYLE:ITALIC;">
	Major Customers
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="TEXT-INDENT:20PT; MARGIN-TOP:6PT; WIDTH:456PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	In the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015, three of our Tier 1 customers represented 31%, 15% and 12% of our total revenues. In the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014, three of our Tier 1 customers represented 33%, 23% and 11% of our total revenues. In the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2013, three of our Tier 1 customers represented 34%, 18% and 11% of our total revenues. Our sales to any single Tier 1 company typically may cover more than one OEM and more than one production program from any OEM and therefore we view major customers on the OEM level. In 2015, sales through our Tier 1 suppliers to each of four OEMs accounted for more than 10% of our OEM revenues. Below is an analysis of OEM and AM major customers:
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE=" FLOAT:LEFT; MARGIN-LEFT:20PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT; MARGIN-TOP:7.39PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-ALIGN:LEFT; WIDTH:20PT;WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP;">
	&#8226;
<BR>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE=" FLOAT:LEFT; MARGIN-TOP:7.39PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT; TEXT-ALIGN:LEFT; WIDTH:415.5PT;">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-WEIGHT:BOLD;">
	OEM
</FONT>
	&#8201;&#8212;&#8201;Set forth below are OEMs that represented at least 10% of our OEM revenues during the three years ended December&nbsp;31, 2015:
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="CLEAR:BOTH; PADDING:0PT; MARGIN:0PT;FONT-SIZE:0PT;LINE-HEIGHT:0PT;">
	&#8203;
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE=" FLOAT:LEFT; MARGIN-LEFT:40PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT; MARGIN-TOP:7.59PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-ALIGN:LEFT; WIDTH:20PT;WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP;">
	&#8226;
<BR>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE=" FLOAT:LEFT; MARGIN-TOP:7.59PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT; TEXT-ALIGN:LEFT; WIDTH:395.5PT;">
	General Motors represented 24%, 30% and 29% of OEM revenues during 2015, 2014 and 2013, respectively;
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="CLEAR:BOTH; PADDING:0PT; MARGIN:0PT;FONT-SIZE:0PT;LINE-HEIGHT:0PT;">
	&#8203;
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE=" FLOAT:LEFT; MARGIN-LEFT:40PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT; MARGIN-TOP:7.59PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-ALIGN:LEFT; WIDTH:20PT;WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP;">
	&#8226;
<BR>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE=" FLOAT:LEFT; MARGIN-TOP:7.59PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT; TEXT-ALIGN:LEFT; WIDTH:395.5PT;">
	Nissan represented 14%, 16% and 10% of OEM revenues in 2015, 2014 and 2013, respectively;
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="CLEAR:BOTH; PADDING:0PT; MARGIN:0PT;FONT-SIZE:0PT;LINE-HEIGHT:0PT;">
	&#8203;
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE=" FLOAT:LEFT; MARGIN-LEFT:40PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT; MARGIN-TOP:7.59PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-ALIGN:LEFT; WIDTH:20PT;WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP;">
	&#8226;
<BR>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE=" FLOAT:LEFT; MARGIN-TOP:7.59PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT; TEXT-ALIGN:LEFT; WIDTH:395.5PT;">
	BMW represented 14%, 14% and 15% of OEM revenues in 2015, 2014 and 2013, respectively; and
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="CLEAR:BOTH; PADDING:0PT; MARGIN:0PT;FONT-SIZE:0PT;LINE-HEIGHT:0PT;">
	&#8203;
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE=" FLOAT:LEFT; MARGIN-LEFT:40PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT; MARGIN-TOP:7.59PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-ALIGN:LEFT; WIDTH:20PT;WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP;">
	&#8226;
<BR>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE=" FLOAT:LEFT; MARGIN-TOP:7.59PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT; TEXT-ALIGN:LEFT; WIDTH:395.5PT;">
	HKMC represented 11% in 2015.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="CLEAR:BOTH; PADDING:0PT; MARGIN:0PT;FONT-SIZE:0PT;LINE-HEIGHT:0PT;">
	&#8203;
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="TEXT-INDENT:20PT; MARGIN-TOP:6PT; WIDTH:456PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	Revenues to each of the above major customers increased in 2015 compared to 2014 in absolute figures while, for some, the percent decreased. This is in line with our expectation that as our business grows, we derive revenues from more OEM customers and our reliance on any specific OEM should decline. For example, in 2015 we had four OEMs representing revenue of over 10% compared to three in 2014, four
</DIV>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:16PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:21.71PT;MARGIN-LEFT:70PT;WIDTH:456PT;">
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:5PT; TEXT-ALIGN:CENTER; WIDTH:456PT; LINE-HEIGHT:11PT;">
	61
</DIV>
</DIV>
<HR>
</DIV>
<A NAME="eolPage64"></A>
<DIV STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-AFTER:ALWAYS; WIDTH:595.3PT;FONT-STYLE:NORMAL;FONT-WEIGHT:NORMAL;FONT-VARIANT:NORMAL;TEXT-TRANSFORM:NONE;COLOR:#000000;FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF;FONT-SIZE:10PT;">
<DIV STYLE="PADDING:0PT;MARGIN:0PT;FONT-FAMILY:CALIBRI, ARIAL, SANS-SERIF;FONT-WEIGHT:NORMAL;FONT-STYLE:NORMAL;FONT-SIZE:8PT;LINE-HEIGHT:8PT;">
<A STYLE="TEXT-DECORATION:NONE;COLOR:#003366;" HREF="#T1600459-20F_HTM_TOC">
	TABLE OF CONTENTS
</A>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:46PT;MARGIN-LEFT:70PT;WIDTH:456PT;">
<DIV STYLE="WIDTH:456PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	OEMs representing revenue of between 5% and 10% of OEM revenue compared to three in 2014 and additional eleven OEMs representing revenue of under 5% compared to eleven in 2014. We believe that as we launch more programs with existing and new OEMs in future years, our reliance on any specific OEM should decline significantly.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE=" FLOAT:LEFT; MARGIN-LEFT:20PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT; MARGIN-TOP:9.98PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-ALIGN:LEFT; WIDTH:20PT;WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP;">
	&#8226;
<BR>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE=" FLOAT:LEFT; MARGIN-TOP:9.98PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT; TEXT-ALIGN:LEFT; WIDTH:415.5PT;">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-WEIGHT:BOLD;">
	AM
</FONT>
	&#8201;&#8212;&#8201;Set forth below are distributors or customers that represented more than 10% of our AM revenues during the three years ended December&nbsp;31, 2015:
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="CLEAR:BOTH; PADDING:0PT; MARGIN:0PT;FONT-SIZE:0PT;LINE-HEIGHT:0PT;">
	&#8203;
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE=" FLOAT:LEFT; MARGIN-LEFT:40PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT; MARGIN-TOP:9.97PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-ALIGN:LEFT; WIDTH:20PT;WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP;">
	&#8226;
<BR>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE=" FLOAT:LEFT; MARGIN-TOP:9.97PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT; TEXT-ALIGN:LEFT; WIDTH:395.5PT;">
	Distributor 1 represented 17% and 14% of our AM revenues during 2015 and 2014, respectively;
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="CLEAR:BOTH; PADDING:0PT; MARGIN:0PT;FONT-SIZE:0PT;LINE-HEIGHT:0PT;">
	&#8203;
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE=" FLOAT:LEFT; MARGIN-LEFT:40PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT; MARGIN-TOP:9.98PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-ALIGN:LEFT; WIDTH:20PT;WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP;">
	&#8226;
<BR>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE=" FLOAT:LEFT; MARGIN-TOP:9.98PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT; TEXT-ALIGN:LEFT; WIDTH:395.5PT;">
	Distributor 2 represented 16% and 6% of our AM revenues during 2015 and 2014, respectively; and
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="CLEAR:BOTH; PADDING:0PT; MARGIN:0PT;FONT-SIZE:0PT;LINE-HEIGHT:0PT;">
	&#8203;
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE=" FLOAT:LEFT; MARGIN-LEFT:40PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT; MARGIN-TOP:9.98PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-ALIGN:LEFT; WIDTH:20PT;WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP;">
	&#8226;
<BR>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE=" FLOAT:LEFT; MARGIN-TOP:9.98PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT; TEXT-ALIGN:LEFT; WIDTH:395.5PT;">
	No other direct customer or distributor represented more than 10% of our AM revenues for any specified period.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="CLEAR:BOTH; PADDING:0PT; MARGIN:0PT;FONT-SIZE:0PT;LINE-HEIGHT:0PT;">
	&#8203;
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="TEXT-INDENT:20PT; MARGIN-TOP:6PT; WIDTH:456PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	We believe that in future years, because of the increase in our revenues, our reliance on any specific distributor should decline significantly.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; WIDTH:456PT; LINE-HEIGHT:11PT;FONT-STYLE:ITALIC;">
	Cost of Sales
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="TEXT-INDENT:20PT; MARGIN-TOP:6PT; WIDTH:456PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	Cost of sales increased during the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015 by $24.4 million, or 65.8%, compared to the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014. The increase correlated to the increased sales of our products. As a percentage of revenues, cost of sales represented 25.5% in 2015, a decrease of 0.3% from 2014. Our Gross Profit for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015 was $179.5 million, an increase of 68.3%, compared to $106.6 million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE=" FLOAT:LEFT; MARGIN-LEFT:20PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT; MARGIN-TOP:9.98PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-ALIGN:LEFT; WIDTH:20PT;WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP;">
	&#8226;
<BR>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE=" FLOAT:LEFT; MARGIN-TOP:9.98PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT; TEXT-ALIGN:LEFT; WIDTH:415.5PT;">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-WEIGHT:BOLD;">
	OEM
</FONT>
	&#8201;&#8212;&#8201;Our 2015 OEM Gross Profit was $153.0 million (gross margin of 75.6%), an increase of 67.2%, compared to $91.5 million (gross margin of 75.1%) for 2014. The increase in Gross Profit resulted from an increase in the volume of products sold as well as changes in product mix.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="CLEAR:BOTH; PADDING:0PT; MARGIN:0PT;FONT-SIZE:0PT;LINE-HEIGHT:0PT;">
	&#8203;
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE=" FLOAT:LEFT; MARGIN-LEFT:20PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT; MARGIN-TOP:9.97PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-ALIGN:LEFT; WIDTH:20PT;WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP;">
	&#8226;
<BR>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE=" FLOAT:LEFT; MARGIN-TOP:9.97PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT; TEXT-ALIGN:LEFT; WIDTH:415.5PT;">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-WEIGHT:BOLD;">
	AM
</FONT>
	&#8201;&#8212;&#8201;Our AM Gross Profit for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015 increased by 75.3% to $26.5 million (gross margin of 68.7%) compared to $15.1 million (gross margin of 69.2%) for 2014. The increase in Gross Profit resulted from increases in the volume of products sold as well as different channel mix
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="CLEAR:BOTH; PADDING:0PT; MARGIN:0PT;FONT-SIZE:0PT;LINE-HEIGHT:0PT;">
	&#8203;
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="TEXT-INDENT:20PT; MARGIN-TOP:6PT; WIDTH:456PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	Cost of sales increased during the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014 by $15.9 million, or 75.3%, compared to the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2013. The increase correlated to the increased sales of our products. As a percentage of revenues, cost of sales represented 25.8% in 2014, a decrease of 0.2% from 2013. Our Gross Profit for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014 was $106.6 million, an increase of 77.3%, compared to $60.1 million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2013.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE=" FLOAT:LEFT; MARGIN-LEFT:20PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT; MARGIN-TOP:9.97PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-ALIGN:LEFT; WIDTH:20PT;WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP;">
	&#8226;
<BR>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE=" FLOAT:LEFT; MARGIN-TOP:9.97PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT; TEXT-ALIGN:LEFT; WIDTH:415.5PT;">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-WEIGHT:BOLD;">
	OEM
</FONT>
	&#8201;&#8212;&#8201;Our 2014 OEM Gross Profit was $91.5 million (gross margin of 75.1%), an increase of 93.1%, compared to $47.4 million (gross margin of 74.9%) for 2013. The increase in Gross Profit resulted from an increase in the volume of products sold as well as changes in product mix.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="CLEAR:BOTH; PADDING:0PT; MARGIN:0PT;FONT-SIZE:0PT;LINE-HEIGHT:0PT;">
	&#8203;
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE=" FLOAT:LEFT; MARGIN-LEFT:20PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT; MARGIN-TOP:9.98PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-ALIGN:LEFT; WIDTH:20PT;WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP;">
	&#8226;
<BR>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE=" FLOAT:LEFT; MARGIN-TOP:9.98PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT; TEXT-ALIGN:LEFT; WIDTH:415.5PT;">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-WEIGHT:BOLD;">
	AM
</FONT>
	&#8201;&#8212;&#8201;Our AM Gross Profit for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014 increased by 18.6% to $15.1 million (gross margin of 69.2%) compared to $12.7 million (gross margin of 71.0%) for 2013. The increase in Gross Profit resulted from increases in the volume of products sold. The 2014 decrease in gross margin resulted mainly from a different channel mix and exchange rate differences.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="CLEAR:BOTH; PADDING:0PT; MARGIN:0PT;FONT-SIZE:0PT;LINE-HEIGHT:0PT;">
	&#8203;
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; WIDTH:456PT; LINE-HEIGHT:11PT;FONT-STYLE:ITALIC;">
	Research and Development Expenses, net
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT:20PT; MARGIN-TOP:6PT; WIDTH:436PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	Research and development expenses in all periods are primarily related to our OEM segment.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="TEXT-INDENT:20PT; MARGIN-TOP:6PT; WIDTH:456PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	Research and development expenses, net as a percentage of revenues decreased to 18.0% for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015 compared to 25.7% for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014, primarily due to the increase in our revenues.
</DIV>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:16PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:21.71PT;MARGIN-LEFT:70PT;WIDTH:456PT;">
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:5PT; TEXT-ALIGN:CENTER; WIDTH:456PT; LINE-HEIGHT:11PT;">
	62
</DIV>
</DIV>
<HR>
</DIV>
<A NAME="eolPage65"></A>
<DIV STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-AFTER:ALWAYS; WIDTH:595.3PT;FONT-STYLE:NORMAL;FONT-WEIGHT:NORMAL;FONT-VARIANT:NORMAL;TEXT-TRANSFORM:NONE;COLOR:#000000;FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF;FONT-SIZE:10PT;">
<DIV STYLE="PADDING:0PT;MARGIN:0PT;FONT-FAMILY:CALIBRI, ARIAL, SANS-SERIF;FONT-WEIGHT:NORMAL;FONT-STYLE:NORMAL;FONT-SIZE:8PT;LINE-HEIGHT:8PT;">
<A STYLE="TEXT-DECORATION:NONE;COLOR:#003366;" HREF="#T1600459-20F_HTM_TOC">
	TABLE OF CONTENTS
</A>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:46PT;MARGIN-LEFT:70PT;WIDTH:456PT;">
<DIV STYLE=" FLOAT:LEFT; MARGIN-LEFT:20PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT; MARGIN-TOP:4PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-ALIGN:LEFT; WIDTH:20PT;WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP;">
	&#8226;
<BR>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE=" FLOAT:LEFT; MARGIN-TOP:4PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT; TEXT-ALIGN:LEFT; WIDTH:415.5PT;">
	Gross research and development expenses increased by $9.2 million, or 19.6%, to $56.0 million for 2015. The increase in 2015 was mainly due to increased headcount, share-based compensation, expenses incurred for EyeQ4
<FONT STYLE=" POSITION:RELATIVE; BOTTOM:4.25PT;FONT-SIZE:7.5PT;">
	&reg;
</FONT>
	development, increase in quality assurance activity by our subcontractor in Sri Lanka and depreciation of IT hardware needed to accommodate our validation dataset.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="CLEAR:BOTH; PADDING:0PT; MARGIN:0PT;FONT-SIZE:0PT;LINE-HEIGHT:0PT;">
	&#8203;
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE=" FLOAT:LEFT; MARGIN-LEFT:20PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT; MARGIN-TOP:8.59PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-ALIGN:LEFT; WIDTH:20PT;WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP;">
	&#8226;
<BR>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE=" FLOAT:LEFT; MARGIN-TOP:8.59PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT; TEXT-ALIGN:LEFT; WIDTH:415.5PT;">
	NRE reimbursement, which offsets our gross research and development expenses, increased by $2.7 million in the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015. In general, Non-Recurring Engineering reimbursement derives from specific development programs with OEMs, and varies based on the length and cost of the specific development program.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="CLEAR:BOTH; PADDING:0PT; MARGIN:0PT;FONT-SIZE:0PT;LINE-HEIGHT:0PT;">
	&#8203;
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE=" FLOAT:LEFT; MARGIN-LEFT:20PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT; MARGIN-TOP:8.58PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-ALIGN:LEFT; WIDTH:20PT;WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP;">
	&#8226;
<BR>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE=" FLOAT:LEFT; MARGIN-TOP:8.58PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT; TEXT-ALIGN:LEFT; WIDTH:415.5PT;">
	As a result, research and development expenses, net increased by $6.5 million, or 17.5%, to $43.4 million for 2015 compared to $36.9 million for 2014.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="CLEAR:BOTH; PADDING:0PT; MARGIN:0PT;FONT-SIZE:0PT;LINE-HEIGHT:0PT;">
	&#8203;
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="TEXT-INDENT:20PT; MARGIN-TOP:6PT; WIDTH:456PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	Research and development expenses, net as a percentage of revenues decreased to 25.7% for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014 compared to 27.5% for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2013, primarily due to the increase in our revenues.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE=" FLOAT:LEFT; MARGIN-LEFT:20PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT; MARGIN-TOP:8.59PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-ALIGN:LEFT; WIDTH:20PT;WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP;">
	&#8226;
<BR>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE=" FLOAT:LEFT; MARGIN-TOP:8.59PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT; TEXT-ALIGN:LEFT; WIDTH:415.5PT;">
	Gross research and development expenses increased by $14.0 million, or 42.6%, to $46.8 million for 2014. The increase in 2014 was mainly due to increased headcount, share-based compensation, depreciation of IT hardware needed to accommodate our validation dataset and an increase in quality assurance activity by our subcontractor in Sri Lanka and expenses incurred for the EyeQ4
<FONT STYLE=" POSITION:RELATIVE; BOTTOM:4.25PT;FONT-SIZE:7.5PT;">
	&reg;
</FONT>
	development.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="CLEAR:BOTH; PADDING:0PT; MARGIN:0PT;FONT-SIZE:0PT;LINE-HEIGHT:0PT;">
	&#8203;
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE=" FLOAT:LEFT; MARGIN-LEFT:20PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT; MARGIN-TOP:8.58PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-ALIGN:LEFT; WIDTH:20PT;WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP;">
	&#8226;
<BR>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE=" FLOAT:LEFT; MARGIN-TOP:8.58PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT; TEXT-ALIGN:LEFT; WIDTH:415.5PT;">
	NRE reimbursement, which offsets our gross research and development expenses, decreased by $0.6 million in the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="CLEAR:BOTH; PADDING:0PT; MARGIN:0PT;FONT-SIZE:0PT;LINE-HEIGHT:0PT;">
	&#8203;
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE=" FLOAT:LEFT; MARGIN-LEFT:20PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT; MARGIN-TOP:8.59PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-ALIGN:LEFT; WIDTH:20PT;WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP;">
	&#8226;
<BR>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE=" FLOAT:LEFT; MARGIN-TOP:8.59PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT; TEXT-ALIGN:LEFT; WIDTH:415.5PT;">
	As a result, research and development expenses, net increased by $14.6 million, or 65.5%, to $36.9 million for 2014 compared to $22.3 million for 2013.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="CLEAR:BOTH; PADDING:0PT; MARGIN:0PT;FONT-SIZE:0PT;LINE-HEIGHT:0PT;">
	&#8203;
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; WIDTH:456PT; LINE-HEIGHT:11PT;FONT-STYLE:ITALIC;">
	Sales and Marketing Expenses
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="TEXT-INDENT:20PT; MARGIN-TOP:6PT; WIDTH:456PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	Sales and marketing expenses as a percentage of revenues decreased to 5.3% for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015 compared to 9.0% for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014, primarily due to the increase in our revenues. Sales and marketing expenses decreased by $0.1 million, or 0.8%, to $12.8 million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015 compared to $12.9 million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014. The decrease was mainly due to decrease in share-based compensation, which is offset by an increase in headcount and advertising expenses as part of marketing efforts attributable to the AM segment in order to reach potential customers worldwide, including fleets, insurance companies, government agencies and vehicle importers and dealers. Excluding the effect of share-based compensation, sales and marketing expenses increased by $3.8 million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="TEXT-INDENT:20PT; MARGIN-TOP:6PT; WIDTH:456PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	Sales and marketing expenses as a percentage of revenues decreased to 9.0% for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014 compared to 15.2% for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2013, primarily due to the increase in our revenues. Sales and marketing expenses increased by $0.6 million, or 4.7%, to $12.9 million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014 compared to $12.3 million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2013. The increase was mainly due to increased marketing efforts attributable to the AM segment in order to reach potential customers worldwide. Without the effect of share-based compensation, sales and marketing expenses increased by $1.2 million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; WIDTH:456PT; LINE-HEIGHT:11PT;FONT-STYLE:ITALIC;">
	General and Administrative Expenses
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="TEXT-INDENT:20PT; MARGIN-TOP:6PT; WIDTH:456PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	General and administrative expenses as a percentage of revenues decreased to 18.9% for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015 compared to 49.7% for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014. The decrease of&#8201; $25.9 million, or 36.3%, to $45.5 million for 2015 compared to $71.4 million for 2014, was mainly due to share-based compensation, primarily to our Founders. General and administrative expenses excluding share-based compensation increased by $3.9 million during 2015, mainly due to expenses related to being a public company audit and accounting fees, patent prosecution costs, business travel and increased headcount.
</DIV>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:16PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:21.71PT;MARGIN-LEFT:70PT;WIDTH:456PT;">
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:5PT; TEXT-ALIGN:CENTER; WIDTH:456PT; LINE-HEIGHT:11PT;">
	63
</DIV>
</DIV>
<HR>
</DIV>
<A NAME="eolPage66"></A>
<DIV STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-AFTER:ALWAYS; WIDTH:595.3PT;FONT-STYLE:ITALIC;FONT-WEIGHT:NORMAL;FONT-VARIANT:NORMAL;TEXT-TRANSFORM:NONE;COLOR:#000000;FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF;FONT-SIZE:10PT;">
<DIV STYLE="PADDING:0PT;MARGIN:0PT;FONT-FAMILY:CALIBRI, ARIAL, SANS-SERIF;FONT-WEIGHT:NORMAL;FONT-STYLE:NORMAL;FONT-SIZE:8PT;LINE-HEIGHT:8PT;">
<A STYLE="TEXT-DECORATION:NONE;COLOR:#003366;" HREF="#T1600459-20F_HTM_TOC">
	TABLE OF CONTENTS
</A>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:46PT;MARGIN-LEFT:70PT;WIDTH:456PT;">
<DIV STYLE="TEXT-INDENT:20PT; MARGIN-TOP:6PT; WIDTH:456PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;FONT-STYLE:NORMAL;">
	General and administrative expenses as a percentage of revenues increased to 49.7% for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014 compared to 12.6% for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2013. The increase was mainly due to share-based compensation, primarily to our Founders (45.6% of revenues). General and administrative expenses increased by $61.2 million, or 595%, to $71.4 million for 2014 compared to $10.3 million for 2013. The increase was primarily attributable to an increase in share-based compensation of&#8201;$60.6 million compared to 2013, mainly related to options granted to our Founders. General and administrative expenses excluding share-based compensation increased by $0.6 million during 2014, mainly related to audit and other expenses related to being a public company and increased headcount, offset by a decrease of&#8201;$2.2 million in litigation expenses.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; WIDTH:456PT; LINE-HEIGHT:11PT;">
	Interest Income
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="TEXT-INDENT:20PT; MARGIN-TOP:5.61PT; WIDTH:456PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;FONT-STYLE:NORMAL;">
	Interest income increased by $1.6 million, or 121.3%, to $2.9 million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015 compared to $1.3 million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014. The increase was primarily due to an increased investment in debentures, as well as full year effect of proceeds from our IPO on August&nbsp;1, 2014.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="TEXT-INDENT:20PT; MARGIN-TOP:6PT; WIDTH:456PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;FONT-STYLE:NORMAL;">
	Interest income increased by $0.2 million, or 23%, to $1.3 million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014 compared to $1.1 million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2013. The increase was primarily due to the $197.4 million of net proceeds from our IPO on August&nbsp;1, 2014.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; WIDTH:456PT; LINE-HEIGHT:11PT;">
	Financial Income (Expenses)
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="TEXT-INDENT:20PT; MARGIN-TOP:5.6PT; WIDTH:456PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;FONT-STYLE:NORMAL;">
	Financial income (expenses) were ($0.9) million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015 compared to $(4.4) million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014. The decrease is mainly due to the expenses resulting from foreign currency losses of&#8201;&#8201;$0.2 million in 2015 compared to $3.1 million in 2014, as a result of limiting our exposure to currency exchange rate risk by maintaining similar levels of assets and liabilities in New Israeli Shekels. Financial income (expenses) were ($4.4) million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014 compared to $1.4 million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2013. The 2014 financial expenses resulted from foreign currency losses of&#8201;&#8201;$3.1 million that derive mainly from the devaluation of the New Israeli Shekel against the U.S. dollar.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; WIDTH:456PT; LINE-HEIGHT:11PT;">
	Taxes on Income
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="TEXT-INDENT:20PT; MARGIN-TOP:5.61PT; WIDTH:456PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;FONT-STYLE:NORMAL;">
	For the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015, our tax expenses were $11.3 million compared to tax expenses of&#8201; $12.3 million and tax benefit of&#8201; $2.3 million for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2014 and 2013, respectively.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="TEXT-INDENT:20PT; MARGIN-TOP:6PT; WIDTH:456PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;FONT-STYLE:NORMAL;">
	The tax rate, as a percentage of our pre-tax income, is significantly affected by our share-based compensation expense, which is mostly a non-deductible expense. The non-deductible share-based compensation expense has decreased by $3.7 million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015 compared to the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014 given the decrease in total share-based compensation expense. Our pre-tax income, excluding share-based compensation expense, is $125 million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015 compared to $59 million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014. The tax expense, as a percentage of pre-tax income, excluding share-based compensation expense, is 9.0% for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015 compared to 20.8% for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="TEXT-INDENT:20PT; MARGIN-TOP:6PT; WIDTH:456PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;FONT-STYLE:NORMAL;">
	Tax expense for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015 decreased by $1 million compared to the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014. The decrease in tax expense was primarily attributable to our internal reorganization, which was completed in the third quarter of 2014 (see &#8220;&#8212; Taxes on Income &#8212;Reorganization&#8221;), and resulted in (i) a reduced tax rate in the entity where most of the taxable income accumulates (MVT became such main entity with reduced tax rate of 9% while before the reorganization such entity was the Cypriot entity under 12.5% tax rate &#8212; see &#8220;&#8212; Taxes on Income&#8221;); and (ii) a decrease in uncertain tax positions expenses primarily with respect to specific uncertain tax positions related to share-based compensation, which does not exist after the reorganization.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="TEXT-INDENT:20PT; MARGIN-TOP:6PT; WIDTH:456PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;FONT-STYLE:NORMAL;">
	For the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014, the increase in revenue was offset by a significant increase in share-based compensation expense, which resulted in a pre-tax loss. Since most of the share-based compensation expense is non-deductible ($71.0 million non-deductible expense out of total share-based compensation expense of&#8201; $76.9 million, which had an impact of&#8201; $7.3 million on our tax expenses for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014), we had taxable income in the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014.
</DIV>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:16PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:21.71PT;MARGIN-LEFT:70PT;WIDTH:456PT;">
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:5PT; TEXT-ALIGN:CENTER; WIDTH:456PT; LINE-HEIGHT:11PT;FONT-STYLE:NORMAL;">
	64
</DIV>
</DIV>
<HR>
</DIV>

	TABLE OF CONTENTS
</A>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:46PT;MARGIN-LEFT:70PT;WIDTH:456PT;">
<DIV STYLE="TEXT-INDENT:20PT; MARGIN-TOP:6PT; WIDTH:456PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	The increase of&#8201; $14.5 million in tax expense for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014 compared to the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2013 is attributable mainly to the increase in taxable income, the increase in uncertain tax positions and the fact that tax expense for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2013 reflected a tax benefit from the release of the valuation allowance on deferred taxes of our Cypriot subsidiary. Moreover, in December&nbsp;2013, given the clear visibility on achieving taxable profits, we released the valuation allowance on deferred taxes of our Cypriot subsidiary since management believed that it was more likely than not that the deferred tax asset would be realized within the foreseeable future. Those tax loss carryforwards were utilized during 2014.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; WIDTH:456PT; LINE-HEIGHT:11PT;FONT-STYLE:ITALIC;">
	Earnings (Loss) Per Share
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="TEXT-INDENT:20PT; MARGIN-TOP:6PT; WIDTH:456PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	Basic earnings (losses) per share are computed by dividing net income or loss applicable to ordinary shareholders by the weighted-average number of ordinary shares. Diluted earnings (losses) per share are calculated by dividing net income or loss applicable to ordinary shareholders by the weighted-average number of ordinary shares, plus the effect of dilutive outstanding equity-based awards which is calculated using the treasury stock method.
</DIV>

</EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<DIV STYLE="TEXT-INDENT:20PT; MARGIN-TOP:13.19PT; WIDTH:456PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	Immediately prior to our IPO, we completed the Share Recapitalization pursuant to which all of our outstanding classes of shares converted into ordinary shares, none of which has any liquidation preference, on a one-to-one basis as set forth in our articles of association.
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="TEXT-INDENT:20PT; MARGIN-TOP:6PT; WIDTH:456PT; LINE-HEIGHT:12PT;">
	Our calculation of earnings (loss) per share has been affected by two factors that cannot recur. The first factor that is applicable to both 2014 and 2013, is that until July&nbsp;31, 2014, shortly prior to our IPO, our issued share capital was composed of Class A ordinary shares (with no liquidation preference), ordinary shares (with liquidation preference), and Class B, C, D, E, F1 and F2 Shares (with liquidation preferences). Prior to our IPO, the only class of outstanding shares without a liquidation preference was the Class A ordinary shares. Therefore, under U.S. GAAP, earnings per share had to be computed based on the outstanding Class A ordinary shares. While the weighted average number of all of our share capital was 207.2 million (basic and diluted) for 2014 and 195.7 million (basic) and 204.9 million (diluted) for 2013, the weighted average number of outstanding Class A ordinary shares was 107.9 million and 37.5 million in 2014 and 2013, respectively, for purposes of both the basic and diluted calculation of loss per share. The other factor that is applicable only to 2013 is that during 2013, as a result of the investment transaction described in Note 8(d) to our audited consolidated financial statements included elsewhere in this Annual Report on Form 20-F, we redeemed 43,456,175 aggregate shares of classes B, C, D, E and ordinary shares (with liquidation preference), which were subsequently converted to Class F1 and Class F2 shares and sold to new investors. In connection with this redemption, we transferred value to the preferred shareholders, which was calculated as the difference between (1) the fair value of the consideration transferred and (2) the carrying value of the 43,456,175 shares of classes B, C, D, E and ordinary shares (with liquidation preferences) surrendered. The difference, in the amount of&#8201;$230 million, was recorded as a reduction to net income applicable to Class A ordinary shares used to calculate basic and diluted loss per share.
</DIV>
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:16PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:21.71PT;MARGIN-LEFT:70PT;WIDTH:456PT;">
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:5PT; TEXT-ALIGN:CENTER; WIDTH:456PT; LINE-HEIGHT:11PT;">
	65
</DIV>
</DIV>
<HR>
</DIV>
